text.div:
PhenopacketsImplementationGuide

The official URL for this implementation guide is: 

http://ga4gh.org/fhir/phenopackets/ImplementationGuide/phenopackets

Phenopackets is an open standard for sharing disease and phenotype information that will improve our ability to understand, diagnose, and treat both rare and common diseases. A Phenopacket links detailed phenotype descriptions with disease, patient, and genetic information, enabling clinicians, biologists, and disease and drug researchers to build more complete models of disease. The standard is designed to encourage wide adoption and synergy between the people, organizations and systems that comprise the joint effort to address human disease and biological understanding. Phenopackets on FHIR is a FHIR implementation guide based on the Phenopackets standard.

name: PhenopacketsImplementationGuide
title: Phenopackets Implementation Guide
description: Phenopackets is an open standard for sharing disease and phenotype information that will improve our ability to understand, diagnose, and treat both rare and common diseases. A Phenopacket links detailed phenotype descriptions with disease, patient, and genetic information, enabling clinicians, biologists, and disease and drug researchers to build more complete models of disease. The standard is designed to encourage wide adoption and synergy between the people, organizations and systems that comprise the joint effort to address human disease and biological understanding. Phenopackets on FHIR is a FHIR implementation guide based on the Phenopackets standard.

grouping.name: Structures: Resource Profiles
grouping.description: These define constraints on FHIR resources that need to be complied with by conformant implementations

grouping.name: Structures: Extension Definitions
grouping.description: These define constraints on FHIR data types that need to be complied with by conformant implementations

grouping.name: Terminology: Value Sets
grouping.description: These define sets of codes used by systems conforming with this implementation guide

grouping.name: Terminology: Code Systems
grouping.description: These define new code systems used by systems conforming with this implementation guide

resource.name: Affected Status
resource.description: Indicates if the individual has the affected phenotype of the proband.

resource.name: Age Or Age Range
resource.description: An age or an age range.

resource.name: Biosample
resource.description: A unit of biological material from which the substrate molecules (e.g. genomic DNA, RNA, proteins) for molecular analyses (e.g. sequencing, array hybridisation, mass-spectrometry) are extracted.

resource.name: Biosample Control
resource.description: Is this a control biosample?

resource.name: Coded Onset
resource.description: The onset of a disease using an ontology class.

resource.name: Cohort
resource.description: A group of individuals related in some phenotypic or genotypic aspect.

resource.name: Diagnostic Markers
resource.description: Clinically relevant bio markers. Most of the assays such as immunohistochemistry (IHC) are covered by the NCIT under the sub-hierarchy NCIT:C36292 (Laboratory Test Result), e.g. NCIT:C68748 (HER2/Neu Positive), NCIT:C131711 (Human Papillomavirus-18 Positive).

resource.name: Disease
resource.description: The word phenotype is used with many different meanings, including 'the observable traits of an organism'. In medicine, the word can be used with at least two different meanings. It is used to refer to some observed deviation from normal morphology, physiology, or behavior. In contrast, the disease is a diagnosis, i.e., and inference or hypothesis about the cause underlying the observed phenotypic abnormalities. Occasionally, physicians use the word phenotype to refer to a disease, but we do not use this meaning here.

resource.name: Evidence
resource.description: This element intends to represent the evidence for an assertion such as an observation of a PhenotypicFeature element.

resource.name: External Reference
resource.description: This element encodes information about an external reference.

resource.name: Family
resource.description: Phenotype, sample and pedigree data required for a genomic diagnosis.

resource.name: Family Identifier
resource.description: A family identifier. Used to export to PED file format.

resource.name: Genome Assembly
resource.description: The genome assembly that a file was called against. We recommend using the Genome Reference Consortium nomenclature e.g. GRCh37, GRCh38.

resource.name: Histological Diagnosis
resource.description: This is the pathologist’s diagnosis and may often represent a refinement of the clinical diagnosis (which could be reported in the Phenopacket that contains this Biosample). Normal samples would be tagged with the term “NCIT:C38757”, “Negative Finding”.

resource.name: Hts File
resource.description: Phenopackets can be used to hold phenotypic information that can inform the analysis of sequencing data in VCF format as well as other high-throughput sequencing (HTS) or other data types.

resource.name: Hts File Reference
resource.description: Reference to a high-throughput sequencing file generated as part of a genomic test.

resource.name: Individual
resource.description: The subject of the Phenopacket is represented by an Individual element. This element intends to represent an individual human or other organism.

resource.name: Individual Reference
resource.description: A reference to an individual associated to a pedigree node.

resource.name: Interpretation
resource.description: Represents the interpretation of a genomic analysis, such as the report from a diagnostic laboratory.

resource.name: Karyotypic Sex
resource.description: The chromosomal sex of an individual.

resource.name: Onset
resource.description: Describes the age at which a phenotypic feature was first noticed or diagnosed.

resource.name: Pedigree Node
resource.description: The Phenopackets Pedigree element represents a PED file, which describes the family relationships of each specimen along with their gender and phenotype. PED files are typically used by software for genetic linkage analysis. PED files have six mandatory columns, and additional optional columns (that are typically not used in the context of genomic analysis). FHIR already has resources and extensions that represent a pedigree. A pedigree node extends the FamilyMemberHistory-Genetic profile.

resource.name: Pedigree Node Reference
resource.description: A reference to a pedigree node.

resource.name: Phenopacket
resource.description: A Phenopacket is an anonymous phenotypic description of an individual or biosample with potential genes of interest and/or diagnoses.

resource.name: Phenopacket Reference
resource.description: An extension to reference a Phenopacket.

resource.name: Phenotypic Feature
resource.description: This element is intended to be used to describe a phenotype that characterizes the subject of the Phenopacket. For medical use cases the subject will generally be a patient or a proband of a study, and the phenotypes will be abnormalities described by an ontology such as the Human Phenotype Ontology. The word phenotype is used with many different meanings including disease entity, but in this context we mean an individual phenotypic feature, observed as either present or absent, with possible onset, modifiers and frequency.

resource.name: Phenotypic Feature Modifier
resource.description: This element is a list of ontology class elements intended to provide more expressive or precise descriptions of a phenotypic feature, including attributes such as positionality and external factors that tend to trigger or ameliorate the feature.

resource.name: Severity
resource.description: The severity of a phenotype.

resource.name: Taxonomy
resource.description: For resources where there may be more than one organism being studied it is advisable to indicate the taxonomic identifier of that organism, to its most specific level.

resource.name: Tumor Grade
resource.description: List of terms representing the tumor grade.

resource.name: Tumor Progression
resource.description: This field can be used to indicate if a specimen is from the primary tumor, a metastasis or a recurrence. There are multiple ways of representing this using ontology terms, and the terms chosen should have a specific meaning that is application specific.

resource.name: Tumor Stage
resource.description: This element can be used if the phenopacket describes cancer. Tumor staging describes the extent of growth of cancer, including the tumor and, if applicable, affected lymph nodes and distant metastases.

resource.name: Variant Reference
resource.description: References a variant observation.

resource.name: Affected Status
resource.description: An enumeration used to represent whether a person is affected by a condition of interest in the context of a pedigree.

resource.name: Diagnostic Markers
resource.description: Codes to indicate clinically relevant bio markers.

resource.name: Evidence
resource.description: Codes from the Evidence & Conclusion Ontology.

resource.name: HTS Format
resource.description: Represents different high-throughput sequencing file formats.

resource.name: HistologicalDiagnosis
resource.description: Histological diagnosis codes from NCIT.

resource.name: Karyotypic Sex
resource.description: Represents the chromosomal sex of an individual.

resource.name: Onset
resource.description: Onset codes from the Human Phenotype Ontology and SNOMED CT.

resource.name: Phenotypic Feature Interpretation
resource.description: Codes to indicate the interpretation of a phenotypic feature (present or absent).

resource.name: Phenotypic Feature Modifier
resource.description: Clinical modifier codes from the Human Phenotype Ontology. TODO: include corresponding codes from SNOMED CT.

resource.name: Phenotypic Feature Type
resource.description: The primary ontology class which describes the phenotype.

resource.name: Severity
resource.description: Phenotypic feature severity codes from the Human Phenotype Ontology and SNOMED CT.

resource.name: Taxonomy
resource.description: Taxonomic identifiers of an organism.

resource.name: Tumor Grade
resource.description: Codes to indicate the grade of a tumor.

resource.name: Tumor Progression
resource.description: Codes to indicate if a specimen is from the primary tumor, a metastasis or a recurrence.

resource.name: Tumor Stage
resource.description: Codes to represent the stage of a tumor.

resource.name: Affected Status
resource.description: An enumeration used to represent whether a person is affected by a condition of interest in the context of a pedigree.

resource.name: Document Type
resource.description: Represents the different types of documents in the Phenopackets standard.

resource.name: HTS Format
resource.description: An enumeration used to represent different high-throughput sequencing file formats.

resource.name: Karyotypic Sex
resource.description: Represents the chromosomal sex of an individual.

resource.name: Section Type
resource.description: Represents the different types of sections in the objects that are built as compositions in the Phenopackets standard.
